cards.back:
A systematic method to solve circuits by:
1. Choosing a reference node (ground)
2. Defining node voltages relative to ground
3. Writing KCL at each non-reference node
4. Solving the resulting system of equations

cards.front: How many equations for N nodes?
cards.back:
For a circuit with N nodes (including ground):

Number of equations = N - 1

One node is reference (ground, 0V), so N-1 unknown node voltages.

cards.front: KCL Equation Form at a Node
cards.back:
At node k with voltage vₖ:

Σ (currents leaving) = 0

Or: Σ (vₖ - vⱼ)/Rₖⱼ = Σ Iₛₒᵤᵣcₑ,ᵢₙ

Current from k to j: I = (vₖ - vⱼ)/R

G_kk = Sum of ALL conductances connected to node k

G_kk = Σ Gⱼ for all j connected to k

(Always positive)

G_kj = NEGATIVE of conductance between nodes k and j

G_kj = -G_between(k,j)

(Always negative or zero)

Note: G is symmetric, so G_kj = G_jk

Use a supernode when a voltage source connects two NON-REFERENCE nodes (floating voltage source).

Supernode gives:
1. Constraint: v₁ - v₂ = V_source
2. Combined KCL: Treat both nodes as one for KCL

If voltage source V connects node k to ground:

vₖ = V (known!)

No equation needed for this node—its voltage is fixed by the source.

Current sources appear DIRECTLY in the KCL equations:

• Source INTO node k: +I in current sum
• Source OUT OF node k: -I in current sum

Current sources are 'nodal-friendly'!

Standard nodal equations:

Gv = i

Where:
• G = (N-1) × (N-1) conductance matrix
• v = node voltage vector
• i = current source vector (+ for into node)

Solve: v = G⁻¹i

Nodal analysis is most efficient when:

✓ Circuit has many current sources
✓ Many parallel branches
✓ Fewer nodes than meshes
✓ You need node voltages

Less ideal when:
✗ Many voltage sources (need supernodes)
✗ More nodes than meshes
